title-group.article-title: Flame-retardant cotton barrier nonwovens for mattresses

article-meta.aff: 1Southern Regional Research Center, ARS, USDA, New Orleans, LA, USA
4Huntsman Corporation, Textile Effects, High Point, NC, USA

author-notes.corresp: Dharnidhar Parikh, Director’s Office, Southern Regional Research Center, ARS, USDA, 1100 Robert E. Lee Blvd., New Orleans, LA 70124, USA. Email: Dharnid.parikh@ars.usda.gov

abstract.p: According to regulation CPSC 16 CFR 1633, every new residential mattress sold in the United States since July 2007 must resist ignition by open flame. An environmentally benign “green,” inexpensive way to meet this regulation is to use a low-cost flame-retardant barrier fabric. In this study, a nonwoven fabric of grey unbleached cotton was treated with a low-cost phosphate-based formulation. The energy-dispersive X-ray microanalysis showed uniform nitrogen and phosphorus distribution. With 17% add-on, the flame-retardant unbleached cotton barrier showed a limiting oxygen index of 33% oxygen and 83 mm of char length with no after-flame and no afterglow in the vertical flame test. Under air and nitrogen at 500°C, 24% and 35% char remained after thermogravimetric analyses, respectively. This flame resistance is comparable to that of current commercial barrier fabrics made from bleached cotton and Flovan cyanoguanidine or from T-bond grey cotton fiber highlofts (Jones Fiber). Mattresses constructed with a flame-retardant cotton nonwoven barrier fabric are predicted to meet the requirements of 16CFR1633. As a follow-up to this study, a full-scale mattress burn test is recommended.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The recent CPSC 16 CFR 1633 standard (effective since July 2007)1 for residential mattresses and mattress-foundation sets is designed to reduce the risk of flashover.2,3 By limiting the amount of heat energy released, this requirement provides additional time for the occupants to escape and provides at least 30 min for the occupants to escape to safety in a fire. The standard requires that a full-scale burn test be done using a pair of T-shaped gas burners.

In North America, the great majority of the residential mattresses are constructed with polyurethane foam (PUF), such as layers of foam, and innersprings with flame-retardant (FR) natural or synthetic fiber barrier fabrics (discussion with Dr Said Nurbakhsh, California Department of Consumer Affairs, 1 June 2012). The open-flame standard has led to the use of barrier fabric for protecting PUF from fire.4 The barrier fabric is placed between the exterior cover fabric (ticking) and the first layer of the cushioning material during the manufacture of mattresses to protect mattresses from the open-flame dual burner test.

The barrier material can be composed of either inherently heat-resistant fiber (such as Kevlar, Nomex, and modacrylic), or charring fibers (such as cotton, rayon, and wool). The expensive FR barrier fibers such as aramid, modacrylic or specialized FR barrier nonwoven (NW)/knit/woven materials can be afforded for expensive mattresses. Our focus has been on the use of charring fibers that must be treated with FR chemicals to be competitive in performance with flame-resistant fibers. Such a treatment on less-expensive grey, that is, unbleached cotton NW fabric will ensure competitive FR test performance at a lower price.

The FR-unbleached cotton barrier fabric deserves special mention because it is natural, biodegradable, and soft to the touch.5 It also costs less than bleached cotton. It is also environmentally beneficial to avoid bleaching, which requires subsequent disposal of the chemicals. The unbleached cotton NW fabric contains 12.5% of polypropylene (scrim) needed to give necessary sturdiness to the fabric.

In the interest of worker and environmental safety, regulatory guidelines suggest that new FR reagents must be effective and nontoxic, and should become innocuous upon reaction with cotton or other substrates. Additionally, volatile byproducts generated during the degradation of treated cotton products should be no more toxic than the volatile products from untreated cotton.

To date, much work has gone into development of an FR system for the FR NW cotton barrier fabric or highloft for mattresses employing either boric acid6 or phosphates. As a result, cotton continues to be a very cost-effective solution for mattress manufacturers.7

The US mattress business is large. For the year 2009, the annual retail value was US$11 billion.8 Approximately 4 lbs of FR fibers are used to make a NW FR barrier for a queen mattress, a queen size mattress being 60 in wide × 80 in long (Ogle S, INDA, 1100 Crescent Green. Suite 115; Cary, NC 27514, sogle@inda.org, communication on 7 December 2009.). If 25 million mattress sets are sold to the US residential market each year, the FR barrier fiber market is about 100 million pounds. As of April 2009, there were 33 suppliers marketing a variety of barrier fabrics.9 Major barrier fibers used in the United States are FR cotton (20 million pounds), FR rayon (65 million pounds), and the balance includes post-treated rayon, wool, Basofil® (melamine fiber), and different blends of inherently FR fibers (15 million pounds). Cotton’s share of the FR barrier market is likely to increase not only in the United States but also globally due to “green” initiatives. This study shows why the increased use of FR grey unbleached cotton barriers would have economic and environmental benefits by replacing expensive and/or nonbiodegradable materials.

For an FR barrier to be effective, it must reduce the actual, recognized hazard (smoldering or flaming combustion or both) and improve fire resistance. To be salable, the final product (mattress) must meet the aesthetic criteria (comfort, appearance) without introducing any health-/safety-related issues.10 FR barriers must be sturdy and durable enough to last the life of the mattress.

Diammonium phosphate, having a long history of use in flame retardancy, has been used as an FR chemical in this work. The USP 5,397,509 relates to a fire retardant composed of certain percentages of dibasic ammonium phosphate, dibasic ammonium sulfate, and ammonium biborate dissolved in water. That solution is applied to the absorbent material/fabric/paper, allowed to soak in, and then dried to create the fire-retardant characteristics in the material/fabric/paper. The composition and the process can be used to make an FR terrycloth blanket that can be used as a safety device to smother fires.11 However, that application and the formulation are different from the current application to a barrier fabric. This is because grey unbleached cotton is much less absorbent than bleached terrycloth. Using a borax–boric acid treatment, Wakelyn et al.12 developed grey unbleached cotton barrier fabrics.

At the Southern Regional Research Center (SRRC), FR barriers have been developed with phosphate-based nondurable (to washing) formulations13 –15 for grey unbleached cotton fabrics. For comparison, a commercially available, nitrogen-containing phosphonic acid salt–based FR chemical, Flovan® cyanoguanidine (CGN; “F”) was acquired from Huntsman Corporation (Huntsman Corporation, High Point, NC, USA, acquired it from CIBA, Europe). It is a CGN (or guanylurea) salt of methylphosphonic acid developed for nondurable FR treatment.16 This product has been utilized for producing FR barrier fabrics (for use in mattresses to meet CFR 1633). Flovan CGN FR finish is suitable for cellulose, polyester, wool, polypropylene, and their blends, and has been successfully tested and utilized on ticking and barrier fabrics to meet CFR 1633 regulations (Ms Betty Tilley, Technical Resource Manager, Huntsman International Textile Effects Division (PH: 704-587-5271), Charlotte, NC: Verbal Communication 8 June 2012.).17 It combines skin compatibility with high protection and has achieved the third-party certification of Oeko-Tex Standard 100.18,19 The formulation based on Flovan CGN was used to produce FR grey unbleached cotton barrier fabrics. The test results of these NW FR cotton barrier fabrics are presented and discussed.

sec.title: Fabrics
sec.p: A roll of grey unbleached cotton needle-punched NW fabric (87.5% cotton with polymer scrim 12.5%), 100 m long, 228.6 cm (90 in) wide, and 150 g/m2 (5 oz/yd2), was donated by the Warm Company (Lynnwood, WA, DC). The grey cotton needle-punched NW fabric without scrim (100 g/m2) was produced at the SRRC and evaluated by the vertical flammability test method to show the effect of scrim.

sec.title: Formulations and application
sec.p: The FR formulations used were (a) FR chemical, Flovan CGN, from Huntsman Corporation and (b) a phosphate–nitrogen based formulation (Table 1) that was developed at SRRC, formulation SRRC-1. Flovan CGN is shown as a nitrogen-containing, phosphonic acid salt–based chemical on the Huntsman data sheet. The FR is a CGN (or guanylurea) salt of methylphosphonic acid developed for nondurable FR treatment.16

fn.p: SRRC: Southern Regional Research Center; DMDHEU: dimethyloldihydroxyethyleneurea resin.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Formulation based on commercially available Flovan cyanoguanidine, 35% aqueous; Flovan was used as supplied with the addition of water and Triton X-100.

fn.label: b
fn.p: DMDHEU: Hylite LF (40%) from National Starch and Chemical Company with ultra-low formaldehyde.

sec.p: The formulation based on Flovan CGN was applied to grey unbleached cotton NW fabric with a Mathis laboratory padder with varying amounts of wet pickup to obtain a range of dry add-on (6.7%–26.2%) for the fabric. The finishing technique involved thoroughly wetting and saturating the grey NWs with the formulation and passing through a padder (one immersion and one nip, two immersions and two nips, or three immersions and three nips). The samples were dried thoroughly in a Mathis forced-air lab dryer on a pin frame for 3 min at 120°C–130°C, depending upon the wet pickup. Table 3 shows the add-ons with two immersions and two nips. The SRRC-1 formulation was applied with a Mathis padder to unbleached cotton NW fabric with two immersions and two nips (Table 4). The thoroughly wetted and saturated fabrics were passed through the first padding at a nip pressure of 90 lbf/in2 and with a speed of 2 m/min to obtain a low wet pickup of about 60%. Fabrics were again saturated in the formulation, and passed through a nip pressure of 10 lbf/in2 at 2 m/min to obtain a wet pickup of about 95%–100%. The samples were placed on a pin frame and dried thoroughly in the forced-air dryer at 135°°C for 2 min 45 s, giving an average add-on of 14.2%.

sec.title: Fabric testing
sec.p: The test evaluations were carried out under standard atmospheric conditions, 65% relative humidity and 70°F. The untreated needle-punched NW fabric (control) as well as the FR-treated samples were evaluated as follows: vertical flame resistance by test method ASTM D 6413/D6413M-11ae1 standard test method for flame resistance of textiles; limiting oxygen index (LOI) by ASTM D 2863-12 standard test method for measuring the minimum oxygen concentration to support candle-like combustion of plastics; percent nitrogen by Dumas combustion; percent phosphorus by AOAC 986.15 with inductively coupled plasma; and breaking strength by “grab test” ASTM D5034-09 standard test method for breaking strength and elongation of textile fabrics. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were run on a model Q500 from TA Instruments (New Castle, DE) with the heating rate of 10°C/min from room temperature to 500°C in air and nitrogen.

Elemental analysis and mapping of NW cotton fabric samples were performed on an FEI XL30 Environmental Scanning Electron Microscope equipped with energy-dispersive X-ray microanalysis (EDAX; Ametek Corp, Mahwah, NJ) Carbon planchets were adhered to standard ½ in Cambridge aluminum stubs using double-sided Avery photo labels (no. 06001). Samples were carbon coated to a thickness of 10 nm. Specimens were observed at 1500× magnification with accelerating voltages of 15–20 kV and a working distance of ∼10 mm.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: Before we discuss our present results, we summarize the salient features of our previous FR research using CA TB603, and the microscale combustion calorimeter (MCC) that are pertinent to the present investigation of FR grey unbleached cotton NW fabrics.20

In 2003, grey unbleached cotton NW fabrics treated with the SRRC-1 formulation were certified as acceptable by the CA Bureau of Home Furnishing and Thermal Insulation based on passing the CA TB 603 test (that is admittedly less stringent than the currently required 16CFR1633).

That previous project used a MCC to evaluate the effectiveness of five FR-treated fabrics as flame-blockers for mattresses (Table 2, reproduced from Ref. 20). The MCC was used to evaluate various factors: heat release rate, peak heat release rate (PHRR), temperature at peak heat release rate, heat release capacity, total heat release (THR), and char yield for those three grey cotton NW barrier fabrics, and two Jones Fiber (Humboldt, TN) highloft FR grey cotton barrier fabrics. Jones Fiber has used 18–20 million pounds of grey cotton annually for the past 10 years to produce T-bond FR highlofts that have been successfully used as a fire-blocker in the production of mattresses that meet 16CFR1633. The T-bond highloft fabrics use a synthetic bonding fiber along with cotton to make the thermally bonded, low-density NW fabric. The comparability of the MCC data for the various treatments in Table 2 suggested that the mattresses constructed with FR grey cotton NW fabric (treated with SRRC-1) would have successfully met the requirements of 16CFR1633. We also found that untreated grey unbleached cotton (the control) consistently showed better flame resistance than untreated bleached cotton (PHRR: 101 vs 235; TPHRR (°C): 354 vs 380; THR: 9.5 vs 10.9; and char yield %: 16.8 vs 6.5).20 As a result, the FR products of grey unbleached cotton exhibit lower heat release rate and PHRR than those of the bleached cotton. An added advantage of not bleaching, besides avoiding the expenses of scouring and bleaching, is that the FR grey unbleached cotton fiber is also softer than the FR-bleached cotton. When cotton’s natural wax is removed (by scouring and bleaching cotton fiber), the fiber-to-fiber friction is increased and the fiber becomes less soft.21

caption.p: FR-treated grey unbleached cotton fiber (microscale combustion calorimeter data)20

tr.th: Jones Fiber grey cotton boric acid treated

fn.p: FR: flame-retardant; SRRC: Southern Regional Research Center; HRC: heat release capacity; PHRR: peak heat release rate; THR: total heat release.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Formulation based on commercially available Flovan cyanoguanidine, 35% aqueous; Flovan was used as supplied with the addition of water and Triton X-100.

sec.p: This study focuses exclusively on the SRRC-1 and Flovan CGN-treated grey cotton needle-punched NW fabrics, evaluated with the vertical flammability test, nitrogen and phosphorus analyses, breaking strength tests, TGA, and scanning electron microscopy with EDAX. The SRRC-1 formulation contains Hylite LF dimethyloldihydroxyethyleneurea resin (DMDHEU) ultra-low free formaldehyde) as supplied (a 40% aqueous solution; Table 1). Stowell and Yang have used DMDHEU in their FR treatments.22 Formaldehyde is an International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) Group I carcinogen and is definitely carcinogenic to humans. DMDHEU is the chemical used in durable press shirts and slacks that are frequently in contact with the skin, so is suitable for use in the manufacture of FR barrier fabrics. Given that the FR barrier fabrics are used under the mattress ticking, there would be even fewer toxicological issues. A mixed catalyst system of magnesium chloride hexahydrate and citric acid (1:1) was used to carry out the low temperature cure.23,24 Triton X-100 was used to ensure efficient wetting of the unbleached grey cotton. Diammonium phosphate and urea were used as FRs in the SRRC-1 formulation and have a history of use in other semidurable cotton fabric applications. Industrial grade chemicals were used to keep the formulation economical.

sec.title: Pickup and add-on
sec.p: Flovan CGN is a proven FR on a range of fibers (Ms Betty Tilley, Technical Resource Manager, Huntsman International Textile Effects Division (PH: 704-587-5271). Charlotte, NC: Verbal Communication 8 June 2012).19 They include bleached cotton but not grey cotton. Our previous findings have shown that the FR products of grey unbleached cotton are superior to those of bleached cotton.20 A technique of two immersions with two passes through a roller nip of a two-roller padder was employed for both Flovan CGN and SRRC-1 formulations to allow for sufficient penetration into the grey unbleached NW fabric; Table 3 shows add-ons. Table 4 shows the finish pickup after first and second padding of the SRRC-1 formulation along with add-ons.

caption.p: Finish pickup and add-on with Flovan cyanoguanidine formulation
Finish pickup and add-on with Southern Regional Research Center-1 formulation

sec.title: Flammability tests
sec.p: Vertical flammability test results of the Flovan CGN formulation and the SRRC-1 formulation are shown in Table 5 along with nitrogen and phosphorus analyses. The standard procedure was performed with a flame contact time of 12 s. The untreated cotton control (150 g/m2) was, of course, highly combustible. It ignited when exposed to flame, the flame propagated, and after-flame continued upon removal of the flame source. Flameless smoldering called afterglow continued until the entire fabric was consumed. The specimen burned forming char with the evolution of combustion gases. The char has a certain degree of integrity, probably due to the scrim, Figure 1(a), whereas the char produced from an untreated grey unbleached cotton needle-punched fabric that was without scrim (100 g/m2) had much less integrity, Figure 1(b). As may be seen, a light char is formed that does not adhere to the sample holder. The FR-treated grey unbleached cotton NW fabrics are self-extinguishing without any after-flame or afterglow (upon removal of the flame source) for the fabrics treated with either formulation (Table 5); an add-on as low as 7.8% produces self-extinguishing fabric. There is no simple relationship between percent add-on of the Flovan CGN formulation and char length measured. This is more true for NW cotton fabric, as illustrated by the result for the Flovan CGN formulation with 22.7% add-on giving 13 mm char, and 13.2% giving 14 mm char. Based on three replicates, char lengths of the Flovan CGN formulation-treated cotton were 7–35 mm, and those of SRRC-1 formulation were 75–108 mm.

caption.p: Char length from vertical flammability test, and percent N and percent P of cotton nonwovens treated with Flovan CGN formulation and SRRC-1 formulation

tr.td: Flames, burns, after-flames, afterglows, and burns completely with char due to scrim

fn.p: CGN: cyanoguanidine; SRRC: Southern Regional Research Center.

caption.p: Vertical flammability testing of (a) grey unbleached cotton NW fabric with scrim (150 g/m2) and (b) SRRC-1 untreated grey unbleached cotton needle-punched fabric without scrim (100 g/m2). Igniting: sample combusts as soon as flame touches.
NW: nonwoven; SRRC: Southern Regional Research Center; FR: flame-retardant.

sec.title: TGA
sec.p: To determine how the FR grey unbleached cotton barrier fabrics perform when exposed to heat, the TGA is a useful technique.25

Figures 2 and 3 show TGA of Flovan CGN and SRRC-1 FR-treated grey unbleached cotton NW fabric. The Flovan CGN samples in Figure 2 are listed in Table 5. The results of the different add-ons essentially overlap in Figure 2, showing decomposition to about 35% char at 500°C, compared to untreated fabric showing 10% char. The FR chemicals reduce the decomposition temperature of cotton by ∼80°C as compared to that of unfinished cotton. These FR chemicals decompose at lower temperatures, releasing water, which helps in achieving flame retardancy.26 Also, the percentage of char formed in FR-treated cotton is significantly higher than that of untreated cotton. Char is essentially carbon, and the oxidation of char causes afterglow.27 Phosphorus compounds are particularly effective in inhibiting afterglow, which is the case with the SRRC-1 and the Flovan CGN FR formulations. The preferred fiber types for use as FR barriers are cotton and regenerated cellulosic fibers because they do not melt like synthetic fibers such as polyester but rather decompose to a charred structure. The char serves a number of functions: it insulates the substrate from the intense heat of the fire and also acts as a barrier, hindering flammable volatile breakdown products from reaching the flame front.28,29

caption.p: Thermogravimetric analysis of Flovan CGN FR-treated grey unbleached cotton nonwoven fabrics in nitrogen. The black line is for the untreated control nonwoven fabric. Each line is an average of 5 runs. The add-ons were obtained by techniques described under the ‘Materials and methods’ section, specifically with one immersion and one nip (low add-ons), two immersions and two nips (medium add-ons), or three immersions and three nips (high add-ons). Untreated control: at 100°C, adsorbed water is released; at 330°C, decomposition of cellulose occurs; char is 10% at 500°C; FR-treated cotton: at 100°C, adsorbed water is released; at 160°C, thermal decomposition and volatilization of FR chemicals; at 250°C, decomposition of FR-treated cellulose occurs; and char is 35% at 500°C.

Thermogravimetric analysis of SRRC-1 FR and Flovan CGN (F) FR-treated grey unbleached cotton nonwoven fabrics. Each line is an average of 5 runs. Black line is for untreated control nonwoven fabric. Around 300°C, the thick blue line for SRRC-1 FR in nitrogen coincides with thick pink line for “F” in nitrogen; both FR nonwovens have char of 35% at 500°C.
SRRC: Southern Regional Research Center; CGN: cyanoguanidine; FR: flame-retardant.

sec.p: TGAs of FR grey unbleached cotton NW fabrics with various add-ons of Flovan CGN are shown in Figure 2. The needle-punched FR fabrics with add-ons in the range of 6.7%–26.2% were studied. Regardless of the add-ons, all the curves (except the control) overlapped closely with each other and a char of nearly 35% was formed at 500°C. The first noticeable result of the effect of heat was the loss of water. Compared to an untreated control, the FR-treated sample had higher char yield and showed higher initial loss in weight at lower temperatures. This is consistent with other observations; the FR additives have a higher release of water that enhances flame resistance.30,31 Weight loss behavior was similar for all percentage add-on values (7%–22%). Figure 3 shows the thermal behavior of the Flovan CGN FR NW fabric and SRRC-1 FR NW fabric in both air and nitrogen. Thus, there are two curves each for the Flovan CGN, SRRC-1, and control fabrics. At 500°C, the char in air for the control was 1% versus 15% in nitrogen; for the Flovan CGN FR formulation, char in air was 24% versus 35% in nitrogen; and for SRRC-1 FR, char in air was 25% versus 35% in nitrogen. In air, the rate of burning was faster at a lower temperature, leaving a lower percentage of char. Figure 3 also shows that the thermal decomposition behaviors of SRRC-1 FR and the Flovan CGN FR grey unbleached cotton NW were comparable.

sec.title: LOI, breaking strength, and elongation
sec.p: The test results of LOI, breaking strength, and elongation at break of FR NWs with the SRRC-1 formulation and with the Flovan CGN FR formulation are shown in Table 6. The LOI (32%) of the FR fabrics is high, at least 50% greater than that of the control fabric (LOI: 20%), confirming improvement in FR quality. With low to high add-on, the breaking strength improved over that of the control. Apparently, the chemical acted as a bonding agent, thereby increasing the breaking strength. With the Flovan CGN finished fabric, as the breaking strength increased, as expected, there was a slight reduction in elongation at break (93.2%, 88.7%, and 95.7%) for the three different add-ons with an exception where the elongation at break improved to 113% for 14.7% add-on. For SRRC-1 formulation-treated fabrics, there was a slight reduction in elongation at break (95.8% and 99.4%) with the exception where the elongation at break improved to 101.7% and 101.2% for add-ons of 17.5% and 16.1%, respectively. The data on breaking strength and elongation at break in Table 5 convey that the FR finishes do not unduly alter the strength properties as compared to the untreated control. The treating grey unbleached cotton with either the Flovan CGN or SRRC-1 formulation FR does not cause adverse effects on strength, elongation, or softness. The percent nitrogen and percent phosphorus on the FR grey unbleached fabric of SRRC-1 and the Flovan CGN formulations are shown in Table 5. Their values increased with increased percent add-on. The synergism of nitrogen and phosphorus on the fabric produced a high-quality FR fabric.32,33 The SRRC-1 formulation gives as good an FR finish as does the commercial treatment with Flovan CGN. An add-on of 17% is recommended on the barrier fabric using the SRRC-1 formulation to ensure that the mattress would pass all the required open-flame dual burner flammability tests to meet with CFR 1633.

caption.p: LOI and retained breaking strength and retained elongation at break of SRRC-1 formulation, as well as compliant formulation Flovan CGN

fn.p: CGN: cyanoguanidine; LOI: limiting oxygen index; SRRC: Southern Regional Research Center.

fn.label: a
fn.p: MD direction, with strength of the control as 100.

sec.title: EDAX analyses
sec.p: The EDAX spectra of FR grey unbleached cotton treated with the SRRC-1 formulation compare well with those of FR cotton treated with the Flovan CGN formulation (Figure 4(a) and (b)) regarding percentages for nitrogen and phosphorus. Their presence on the fiber is evidence of FR add-on. The dot map images of elements nitrogen and phosphorus show good distribution throughout the fiber for both the treatments, a typical example is shown in Figure 5. Having a uniform distribution of the FR chemicals throughout the web is important for achieving an efficient FR treatment; the SRRC-1 treatment has successfully accomplished this. Although only one figure is shown, several images were collected and confirmed uniform nitrogen and phosphorus distribution. The EDAX spectra of the untreated grey control cotton (not shown) showed no elemental peaks for nitrogen and phosphorus.

caption.p: The EDAX spectra of FR grey unbleached cotton treated with (a) Flovan CGN for formulation and (b) SRRC-1 formulation.
EDAX: energy-dispersive X-ray analysis; FR: flame-retardant; SRRC: Southern Regional Research Center; CGN: cyanoguanidine.

The SEM image and EDAX elemental dot maps of cotton nonwoven fabric treated with SRRC-1 FR show uniform distribution of nitrogen and phosphorus on cotton fibers: (a) SEM; (b) carbon map; (c) phosphorus map; and (d) nitrogen map.

sec.title: Application to full-scale mattress tests
sec.p: The flammability performance of the SRRC-1 formulation-treated grey unbleached cotton NW fabric was comparable to that of the Flovan-treated fabric as well as that of the commercially successful T-bond grey unbleached cotton highloft fabric (Jones Fiber). This is a positive indication that the mattresses constructed with unbleached, NW cotton FR barrier fabrics would pass 16CFR1633. The inexpensive unbleached fabric approach to an FR barrier is already used in the commercially successful T-bond grey unbleached cotton highloft fabric to comply with Federal open-flame standard.

As a follow-up to this study, we recommend constructing mattresses with a grey unbleached cotton NW fabric treated with the phosphate-based SRRC-1 formulation, and performing the full-scale burn test of whole mattresses.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: The FR characteristics of grey unbleached NW cotton fabric treated with either Flovan CGN formulation or the SRRC-1 formulation were studied. Both formulations produced comparable FR cotton fabrics. The grey unbleached cotton enabled the FR cotton NW to be especially economical. The unbleached cotton is less expensive and softer to the touch than the bleached cotton, thus increasing the marketability for low-to-medium value mattresses. Scouring/bleaching increases the price significantly by a factor of more than 2, and uses chemicals that must be disposed of in an environmentally benign way. The gray color of the unbleached cotton of our FR fabric should not pose a problem when used as a hidden barrier fabric. The mattresses constructed with FR cotton unbleached NW barrier fabric are predicted to meet the requirements of 16CFR1633.

ack.p: We are very thankful to Dr Edward Weil, Research Professor, Polytechnic Institute of NYU; Dr Alfred French, SRRC, Ryan Trainer, Executive Vice President and General Counsel, ISPA; Steve Ogle, Director of Technical Affairs, INDA; and Dr Nicolette Prevost, SRRC, for helpful discussions and suggestions, and to Jade Smith and Crista Madison, SRRC, for test evaluations. We thank Jim Chumbly, President, Warm Company, for donating the grey cotton nonwoven fabric. We also thank Susan Martin and Suhad Wojkowski, Librarians at SRRC-USDA, for their help in obtaining and verifying the references.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research was funded by appropriations to the US Department of Agriculture.

bio.title: Author biographies
bio.p: Dharnidhar Parikh is a retired Materials Research Engineer (retired: April, 2011) from the Agricultural Research Services, US Department of Agriculture in New Orleans, LA with over 225 publications. He has B.S. Textile Chemistry, Bombay University, and Ph.D. from The University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology (UMIST), England. He has received many grants and the Merit scientist award: National Research and Development Corporation, Government of India, and TAAPI Nonwovens Technical Award and Hollingsworth Prize in recognition of his outstanding contributions.

Mr. Ingber is a support scientist biologist working for the Cotton Structure and Quality Research Unit, SRRC-USDA-ARS in New Orleans, LA. Mr. Ingber started in 1972 working for Dr. William Wergin at the Southern Weed Science Lab in Stoneville, MS and the Electron Microscopy Research Unit in Beltsville, MD. He transferred to SRRC in 1982 where he has been an electron microscopist. He has co-authored 50 research articles. He has BA, Biology, Northeastern University in Boston, and MS in plant pathology from the University of Massachusetts in Amherst. He also served two years in the Peace Corps in Malawi, Africa.

Ms. Sunghyun Nam is a research materials engineer with the US Department of Agriculture in New Orleans, LA., USA. She graduated from Georgia Institute of Technology with a PhD in Polymer, Textile, and Fiber Engineering. Her research interests include flame retardant and antimicrobial cotton.

Dr. Gajanan S. Bhat is professor, Materials Science and Engineering, and Director of the University of Tennessee Nonwovens Research Lab. His research covers nonwovens - melt blown, spun-bonded and biodegradable, plastics recycling, sustainable materials, flame retardant nonwovens, and high performance fibers. Lately, he has started production of nanofibers from thermoplastic polymers by the meltblowing process, a revolutionary development for the industry. He has served as the president of the Fiber Society, and is an active member of INDA, TAPPI and the Textile Institute.

Dr. Mary M. Warnock is Professor of Apparel Studies, with an emphasis in Textile Science, in the School of Human Environmental Sciences at the University of Arkansas, Fayetteville, AR. Research topics include flammability as related to mattresses and firefighter uniforms; soil burial on biodegradation properties of woven and nonwoven fabrics. She also served as the Director of the School of Human Environmental Sciences for several years.

Mr. Lee Harrington III is a technical expert on flame retardancy and flame retardant chemicals at Huntsman Corporation Textile Effects, 4050 Premium Drive, High Point, NC. He co-operated with the scientists at the Southern Regional Research Center, New Orleans, LA, and provided technical support in designing experimental work reported.
